articles.summary:
Twitter is facing complaints from companies that don't want their
advertisements next to inappropriate content
articles.title: Advertisers to Twitter: Keep my ads off your porn (CBS News)

articles.summary:
BRENHAM, Texas (AP) -- Blue Bell Creameries says it will be at least several
months before its products are back in stores as the Texas-based company works
to resume operations after a series of listeria illnesses linked to its ice
cream prompted a total product recall....
articles.title: Blue Bell: Several months before ice cream back in stores (The Arizona Republic)

articles.summary:
A dog owner was horrified to find her beloved chihuahua was pecked to death by
a gang of angry seagulls. Nikki Wayne, 57, had previously spotted the birds
diving for five-month-old Bella and never let her pet play unsupervised
outside...
articles.title: Chihuahua pecked to death by gang of angry seagulls (APN)
Chi-Jen Yang quoted: In China, a tug of war over coal gas -- cleaner air, worse for the climate (Duke)

articles.author: By The Associated Press
articles.summary:
A video showing workers at a pig farm hitting animals with cans and boards
prompted the firings of seven employees, but the authorities said Wednesday no
criminal charges would be filed.
articles.title: Colorado: Pig Handlers Fired for Abuse (New York Times)

articles.author: Katie Thomas
articles.summary:
Johnson & Johnson named the bioethicist Arthur L. Caplan to create a panel to
decide on patients’ requests for lifesaving medicines before they are
approved.
articles.title: Company Creates Bioethics Panel on Trial Drugs (NY Times)

articles.author: Nature World: Brian Stallard
articles.summary:
Nature World: Ever since it was first noticed in 2006 that America's honeybees
were dying en masse, the spotlight has been on these essential pollinators. It
was quickly revealed that not only US honeybees, but entire global populations
were in trouble, with troubling declines in Europe and even Australia. Now a
new investigation has revealed that a suite of diseases that once exclusively
affected domestic honeybees has moved on to infect wild bees, such as the
common bumblebee, as well. That's at least according...
articles.title: Dangerous Honeybee Diseases Jump to Wild Pollinators (climateark)

articles.author: Jennifer Viegas
articles.summary: Dogs connect so deeply to people that their hormones synchronize with ours.
articles.title: Dogs' Hormones Adjust to Match Those of Owners (Discovery)

articles.summary:
A batch of straw houses have gone on sale in the UK - and their manufacturers
insist that unlike the home featured in classic nursery rhyme The Three Little
Pigs, huffing and puffing will not lead the buildings to blow down.
articles.title: Huffing and puffing won't blow these straw homes down (reuters)

care in 14 hospitals in the US and Canada, it has been announced. Using
computers to trawl through vast amounts of medical data speeds up the
diagnosis … Read More
articles.title: IBM’s Watson Supercomputer to Speed Up Cancer Care (bioethicscom)

articles.summary:
https://youtu.be/8iNet2WkHkU In early March, I wrote that Arctic sea ice
appeared to be heading toward a new record: the lowest maximum winter extent
for Arctic sea ice in the satellite era. Yesterday, the National Snow and Ice
Data Center made that new, unsettling record official: On February 25, 2015,
Arctic sea ice extent appeared to have reached its annual maximum extent,
marking the beginning of the sea ice melt season. This year’s maximum extent
not only occurred early; it is also t
articles.title: It's Now Official: Arctic Sea Ice Sets a New Winter Low (Discover Magazine)

articles.summary:
Mice exposed to radiation akin to what astronauts to Mars would receive
experienced cognitive impairment. Lee Billings reports.


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com

articles.author: Evan Gough
articles.summary:
NASA has been grabbing headlines recently with their potentially game-changing
emDrive propulsion system. The emDrive has generated a lot of discussion, and
a lot of controversy too. But NASA has a lot more going on than futuristic
space travel designs, and one recent test flight showed that the minds at NASA
are still working on […]
articles.title: NASAs Ten-Engine Electric Plane (Universe Today)

articles.author: Sabrina Toppa
articles.summary: The teeth are used by the islanders as a currency
articles.title: People on the Solomon Islands Have Killed Over 15,000 Dolphins For Their Teeth (TIME)

articles.summary:
(_Uppsala University_) In a new study, published in Nature this week, a
research team led from Uppsala University in Sweden presents the discovery of
a new microbe that represents a missing link in the evolution of complex life.
The study provides a new understanding of how, billions of years ago, the
complex cell types that comprise plants, fungi, but also animals and humans,
evolved from simple microbes.
articles.title: Researchers discover missing link in the evolution of complex cells (Eurekalert)

articles.summary:
A new study on the impact of 'drive-hunting' dolphins in the Solomon Islands
is casting a spotlight on the increasing vulnerability of small cetaceans
around the world. From 1976 to 2013, more than 15,000 dolphins were killed by
villagers in Fanalei alone, where a single dolphin tooth can fetch the
equivalent of 70 cents -- an increase in value of five times just in the last
decade.
articles.title: Solomon Islands dolphin hunts cast spotlight on small cetacean survival (Eurekalert)

articles.author: Sean Paling and Stephen Sadler
articles.summary:

diversifying into areas such as astrobiology and earth sciences
articles.title: Subterranean science (Physicsworld)

articles.summary:
Scientists have introduced genes into the American chestnut from wheat that
help disarm the fungus that killed almost all three billion of the trees in
the eastern U.S. David Biello reports.


-- Read more on ScientificAmerican.com
articles.title: Wheat Genes Could Bring Back Chestnut (Scientific American)
